WRITING.TEXT: It's pretty worn away, but the bottom line looks like a name, Herz Lefek. The upper lines are probably yiddish (which I don't read); they have a lot of the letters ayin and aleph, which are common in Yiddish to help represent the German-based sounds, but aren't very common in this way in Hebrew. At the very bottom I can read the Hebrew letters nun-tzadik-fay, which is part of an initialism for the Hebrew phrase [May his soul be bound up in eternal life](http://jewishliteracy.blogspot.com/2010/06/matzevah-unveiling-of-tombstone.html).

With the formation of those first hydrogen atoms each made of one negatively charged electron and one positively charged proton the universe entered a period cosmologists call the Dark Ages. During this time, the universe quietly waited for clouds of hydrogen to obey the influence of gravity and collapse into the very first stars and galaxies. The ignition of the first stars marks the end of the Dark Ages and the beginning of our Cosmic Dawn, some 100 million years after the Big Bang.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL the universe was entirely dark in the first 100 million years after the Big Bang, until clouds of hydrogen condensed into the first stars

Resarchers drew on the publicly available American Time Use Survey.This is an annual effort of the US Bureau of Labor Statistics querying around 10,000 people every year on their daily schedule of activities. We pulled out all activities involving watching television and video, and grouped the US population according to their watching patterns.
The results were, to us, shocking. The differences are enormous. Dividing the population into heavy, light, and in-between groups:
* The heavy-watchers group is 14% of the population and watches television 7.7 hours day. * The light watchers are 54% of the population and watches 1.1 hours a day. * The in-between group is 33% of the population and watches 3.5 hours.
And those heavy watchers contribute mightily to climate emissions from electricity.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL 14% of the US population watches television for an average of 7.7 hours a day

WRITING.TEXT:
Discovered more than 30 years ago in soil samples from the Polynesian island of Rapa Nui, rapamcyin is perhaps the leading contender in the race for the first anti-aging drug.
It is already FDA-approved for use as an immune suppressant that reduces organ rejection in kidney transplants. It is also used to treat certain cancers, since it can stop cells from growing.
In 2009, researchers made another observation about this versatile drug: when fed to mice at the equivalent age in humans of 60 years, it gave them a boost in life expectancy an impressive 38% in female mice and 28% in male mice. It has also been proven to extend lifespan in yeast, worms and fruit flies.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL a drug used to prevent the rejection of transplanted kidneys also extends the life of elderly mice by 38%

Well, the state gambling commission does have some leverage: they've been negotiating with the Wampanoag on giving them the license designated for SE Massachusetts. That would require the tribe to give the state the same cut of profit as the other casinos in the state.
If the Wampanoag don't agree, then the state will give a license to someone else to build a competing casino nearby, which would split the market and probably make the Wampanoag get less money than signing an agreement with the state.
But I think the Wampanoag are playing hardball negotiating by trying to scare away any possible competitors.

WRITING.TITLE: Native American gambling coming to MA as tribe breaks ground on casino in Taunton

WRITING.TEXT: During a fishing trip in the Bahamas in 1935, he rather unconventionally opened fire on a shoal of sharks with a Thompson submachine-gun to stop them scavenging the humungous tuna he was trying to land. Unfortunately, the explosion of blood simply caused them to attack his catch with even greater fury. His other techniques were more successful. In 1938, he established a world record by catching seven marlin in one day. He was also the first person to ever boat a giant tuna in an undamaged state.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that Ernest Hemingway once fired a sub-machine gun at sharks that attacked a tuna he was trying to land; the blood from the bullets caused the sharks to attack even harder

Could someone explain the editorializing violation put on this? According to the article, Darwin had a hypothesis; an experiment was done that did not support it; thus, the hypothesis is disproven.
Granted, I might have written "Darwin proved wrong on a very minor hypothesis of his", but I felt that the overall headline made it clear that we were not talking about his whole theory of natural selection.

This is a great point that is often forgotten in all of our religion vs. science debates.

Like Donald Trump, Wendell Willkie was a former Democrat, who reregistered as a Republican only later in life. Like Trump, he came to politics from the corporate world and an office in Manhattan. And also like Trump, Willkie came to national prominence through his skillful use of the national media.
Also: Widely covered in the press, Willkie came across as a common-sense critic of the New Deal as something that could and sometimes did go too far.
Next came a triumph in the broadcast entertainment media, in another parallel to Donald Trumps role on his Apprentice TV show.
Radio.

WRITING.TITLE: The real precedent for Trump: Wendell Wilkie, the anti-GOP establishment candidate of 1940

WRITING.TEXT:
Back in 1880, Charles Darwin showed that when you grow plants along a slanted surface, the roots dont grow straight away from the seed, but rather take a jog to one side. This root growth strategy is called skewing. Darwin hypothesized that a combination of gravity and the root touching its way across the surface was behind it - and for 130 years, thats what everyone else thought too.
But in 2010, we saw that the roots of the plants we grew on the ISS marched across the surface of their Petri plate in a perfect example of root skewing no gravity required. It was quite a surprise.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that Darwin was proven wrong by astronauts: he believed plant roots grow sideways because of gravity, but plants grown on the ISS also have skewed roots

WRITING.TEXT:
In the brain, reading music is a widespread, multi-modal activity, meaning that many different areas of the brain are involved at the same time.... While text and music reading share some networks, they are largely independent.
And: Differences in reading ability can occur even within musical notation. Cases have been reported where musicians have lost their ability to read pitch, but retained their ability to read rhythm, and vice versa. fMRI studies have confirmed that the brain processes pitch (spatial information) and rhythm (symbol recognition) differently.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL that the ability to read music uses different parts of the brain than reading words, and there are cases where a stroke has caused people to lose one ability but not the other

### submission statement Last week satellite pictures confirmed that the Islamic State had razed to the ground Iraqs oldest Christian monastery, Saint Elijah, outside the city of Mosul.
The University of South Florida and other researchers are using 3D-imaging technology -- including laser scanners -- to recreate the monastery, and preserve other priceless sites and artifacts, and even share them more widely with the world.
